material-1.title: Façade materials
material-1.question: What materials are present on your building's exterior envelope (i.e., external walls, balconies, porches, etc.)? (excluding shutters)
material-1.description: Combustible façade elements (e.g., timber, vinyl) are vulnerable to all types of wildfire ignitions. Even firebrands or low-intensity flames may ignite a timber or vinyl façade element, while bricks and concrete elements resist much better to fire. Wooden porches entail a large horizontal surface on which firebrands (burning particles that come from the fire) may land. Their close contact with the garden floor also makes them vulnerable to direct flame contact.

Q1.title: Exterior envelope
Q1.question: What percentage of the building's exterior envelope (i.e., external walls, balconies - excluding window shutters and porches) is made of combustible materials?
Q1.description: Materials such as timber or vinyl are combustible, while concrete, stones and bricks are non-combustible.
Q1.more50comb: More or equal to than 50% combustible

Q2.title: Exterior envelope
Q2.question: Is there a non-combustible foundation?
Q2.description: The foundation of a building is the element of the façade that connects to the ground.
Q2.height0: No, the foundation is also combustible
Q2.height0to20: Yes, with a height between 0 and 20 cm
Q2.height21to40: Yes, with a height between 21 and 40 cm
Q2.height41to60: Yes, with a height between 41 and 60 cm
Q2.height61to80: Yes, with a height between 61 and 80 cm
Q2.height81to100: Yes, with a height between 81 cm and 1 m
Q2.heightMore100: Yes, with a height of more than 1 m

Q3.title: Roof
Q3.question: Is your roof covering or your roof assembly made of fire-rated materials (e.g. clay tiles, concrete tiles, asphalt glass fibre composition singles, slate, etc.)?
Q3.description: Examples of fire-rated roof coverings are shown in the following pictures:
Q3.roofNonFireRated: No, some parts are made of non-fire rated materials

Q4-1.title: Roof
Q4-1.question:
Does your roof present any of the following? 
- Broken or missing tiles 
- Exopsed sheeting 
- Unsealed spaces between the roof and external walls 
- Cleaning of debris piling up on roof or gutters is not regularly performed

Q4-2.title: Roof
Q4-2.question:
Does your roof present any of the following? 
- Broken or missing tiles 
- Exopsed sheeting 
- Unsealed spaces between the roof and external walls 
- Cleaning of debris piling up on roof or gutters is not regularly performed

Q5.title: Glazing systems
Q5.question: What is the type of glazing of windows and glass doors?
Q5.description: If your building presents more than one type of glazing systems, select the most representative option.

Q6.title: Glazing systems
Q6.question: Are all glazing systems protected by shutters? If yes, which material are the shutters made of?
Q6.description: Shutters can protect the glazing from the impact of the fire. Important: to block the heat coming from the fire, shutters and shutter slats should be completely closed.
Q6.noShutters: Not all glazing systems are protected by shutters

Q7.title: Vents
Q7.question: What type of protection is placed in front of ventilation openings?
Q7.description: Typical types of vents found in houses are roof openings for attic ventilation (e.g. vent tiles, ridge closer vents), chimneys, and openings for the ventilation of kitchens.
Q7.nonCombGoodCond: The protection is non-combustible in good conditions (no damage)
Q7.nonCombBadCond: The protection is non-combustible, rusted or damaged

vents-2.title: Vents
vents-2.question: What type of protection is placed in front of ventilation openings?
vents-2.description: Ventilation openings are potential entry points for firebrands that could ignite the building from inside. Typical types of vents found in houses are roof openings for attic ventilation (e.g. vent tiles, ridge closer vents), chimneys, and openings for the ventilation of kitchens. Vents should be screened with corrosion-resistant, non-combustible wire meshes (e.g. aluminium, galvanized steel, stainless steel, copper, intumescent coating), with a characteristic length small enough to prevent the pass of firebrands (< 2mm).
vents-2.nonCombBadCond: Non-Combustible in bad condition (rusted or damaged)

Q8.title: Semi-confined space adjacent to house
Q8.question: Is there a semi-confined space adjacent to your house (i.e., it has at least one wall in common with the house) that contains combustible materials?
Q8.description: Semi-confined spaces are areas that are partially open, such as those located under terraces, porches, decks, eaves or canopies, or the spaces enclosed in open sheds.

Q9.title: Semi-confined space adjacent to house
Q9.question: Are there any unprotected (i.e., no shutters) glazing systems (e.g., glass doors or windows) connecting the semi-confined space with the interior of the building?

Q10.title: Semi-confined space
Q10.question: What materials are the walls of the envelope that are shared with the building made of?
Q10.nonCombThin: Non-combustible materials such as aluminium or steel (e.g., shutters without glazing - such as a garage door)
Q10.nonCombThick: Non-combustible materials such as bricks or concrete

I1.title: House surroundings
I1.text: Next, you will answer questions about the surroundings of your house

Q11-1.title: Fuels located close to the building
Q11-1.question: Are fuels such as ornamental vegetation or other types of combustible elements located at least 7 m from glazing systems?
Q11-1.description: Wooden decks (not porches) should be also considered in this question, as they might be ignited by firebrands or flames coming from the garden. Also combustible man-made fuels (e.g., plastic or wooden garden furniture) should be considered.

Q11-2.title: Fuels
Q11-2.question: Are all fuels (vegetation or other types of combustible elements) located at least 5 m from glazing systems?
Q11-2.description: Wooden decks (not porches) should be also considered in this question, as they might be ignited by firebrands or flames coming from the garden. Also combustible man-made fuels (e.g., plastic or wooden garden furniture) should be considered.

Q12.title: Fuels
Q12.question: Are fuels such as ornamental vegetation or other types of combustible elements located at least 5 m from the roof?
Q12.description: Trees that have branches that hang over the roof should be considered as fuels located close to the roof.

Q13.title: Fuels
Q13.question: Are fuels (artificial and flammable vegetation) placed so that they are not located directly against the façade that contains combustible elements? (this includes combustible decks).
Q13.description: Timber decks can also be considered as fuels that can be attached to the building envelope, especially if the foundation is combustible.

Q14.title: Fuels
Q14.question: Is there discontinuity of surface combustible elements within 10 m from the building?
Q14.description: An example of a continuous surface of combustible elements is a grass lawn that has no interruptions within the 10 m radius around the building.
Q14.contSurf: No, there is a continuous combustible surface

Q15.title: Artificial fuels
Q15.question: Are combustible materials (e.g., vegetation, storage spaces, combustible building systems) located at least 2 m from an above ground Liquified Petroleum Gas (LPG) tank (this includes also canisters with a total volume > 0.5 m3)?
Q15.description: The following images show examples of fuels located close to LPG tanks.

Q16.title: Artificial fuels
Q16.question: Is the distance between artificial fuels or fuel packs at least 5 m?

Q17.title: Artificial fuels
Q17.question: In case of wild vegetation of mainly trees located further than 30 m from the building, are artificial fuels located in the Home Ignition Zone placed at a distance of minimum 20 m from these trees?
Q17.description: Artificial fuels such as cars, garden furniture, garden sheds can be located close to wildland vegetation even if this vegetation is not located within the property.
Q17.noPlacement: Not applicable (there are no artificial fuels on my property)

Q18.title: Vegetation
Q18.question: Is the wildland vegetation located at least 30 m from the building?
Q18.description: This wildland vegetation can be treated on untreated. Examples are given in the following pictures.

Q19.title: Vegetation
Q19.question: What type of vegetation is predominantly present within 30 m from the building?
Q19.highFlam: Highly flammable (e.g., pine trees, eucalyptus, cypress, laurel)
Q19.lowFlam: With low flammability (e.g., olive trees, lavender, citrus trees)

Q20.title: Vegetation
Q20.question: Is there discontinuity between tree crowns, shrubs, hedges and other vegetation?
Q20.description: Horizontal discontinuity means to increase the distance between vegetation groups. This can be obtained by separating groups of vegetation from each other.

Q21.title: Vegetation
Q21.question: Is low vegetation (e.g., grass, small shrubs) max 10 cm deep?
Q21.description: An example of low surface fuels is a grass lawn.

Q22.title: Vegetation
Q22.question: Is there dead vegetation or vegetative debris?
Q22.description: Dead vegetative debris are dead leaves, pine needles, etc.

Q23.title: Vegetation
Q23.question: Are trees located within 30 m of the building pruned?
Q23.description: Pruning means to remove the lower branches of a tree

Q24.title: Property perimeter and location within the landscape
Q24.question: What is the predominant delimitation between your property and the neighboring ones?
Q24.concreteMore2: Concrete or brick fence/wall (at least 2 m high)
Q24.concreteLess2: Concrete or brick fence/wall (less than 2 m high)
Q24.noDelimitation: There is no fence or physical delimitation

Q25.title: Property perimeter and location within the landscape
Q25.question: What type of terrain is your property located on?
